Cay S. Horstmann

Chapter 4

Interfaces and Polymorphism

Chapter Topics [2/41]

  • Displaying an Image 
  • Polymorphism
  • The Comparable Interface
  • The Comparator Interface

Displaying an Image [3/41]

  • Use JOptionPane to display message:
    JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(null, "Hello, World!");
  • Note icon to the left

Displaying an Image [4/41]

  • Can specify arbitrary image file
    JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(
     null, 
     "Hello, World!",
     "Message",
     JOptionPane.INFORMATION_MESSAGE,
     new ImageIcon("globe.gif"));

Displaying an Image [5/41]

  • What if we don't want to generate an image file?
  • Fortunately, can use any class that implements Icon interface type
  • ImageIcon is one such class
  • Easy to supply your own class

The Icon Interface Type [6/41] 

public interface Icon
{
 int getIconWidth();
 int getIconHeight();
 void paintIcon(Component c, Graphics g, int x, int y)
}

Interface Types [7/41]

  • No implementation
  • Implementing class must supply implementation of all methods
  • showMessageDialog expects Icon object
  • Ok to pass MarsIcon

file:horstmann/ch04_icon2/MarsIcon.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package horstmann.ch04_icon2;
00002: import java.awt.*;
00003: import java.awt.geom.*;
00004: import javax.swing.*;
00005: 
00006: /**
00007:    An icon that has the shape of the planet Mars.
00008: */
00009: public class MarsIcon implements Icon
00010: {
00011:    /**
00012:       Constructs a Mars icon of a given size.
00013:       @param aSize the size of the icon
00014:    */
00015:    public MarsIcon(int aSize)
00016:    {
00017:       size = aSize;
00018:    }
00019: 
00020:    public int getIconWidth()
00021:    {
00022:       return size;
00023:    }
00024: 
00025:    public int getIconHeight()
00026:    {
00027:       return size;
00028:    }
00029: 
00030:    public void paintIcon(Component c, Graphics g, int x, int y)
00031:    {
00032:       Graphics2D g2 = (Graphics2D) g;
00033:       Ellipse2D.Double planet = new Ellipse2D.Double(x, y,
00034:             size, size);
00035:       g2.setColor(Color.RED);
00036:       g2.fill(planet);
00037:    }
00038: 
00039:    private int size;
00040: }
00041:

file:horstmann/ch04_icon2/IconTester.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package horstmann.ch04_icon2;
00002: import javax.swing.*;
00003: 
00004: public class IconTester
00005: {
00006:    public static void main(String[] args)
00007:    {
00008:       JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(
00009:             null, 
00010:             "Hello, Mars!",
00011:             "Message",
00012:             JOptionPane.INFORMATION_MESSAGE,
00013:             new MarsIcon(50));
00014:       System.exit(0);
00015:    }
00016: }
00017: 
00018:

The Icon Interface Type and Implementing Classes [8/41]



Polymorphism [9/41]

  • public static void showMessageDialog(...Icon anIcon)
  • showMessageDialog shows
    • icon
    • message
    • OK button
  • showMessageDialog must compute size of dialog
  • width = icon width + message size + blank size
  • How do we know the icon width?
    int width = anIcon.getIconWidth();

Polymorphism [10/41]

  • showMessageDialog doesn't know which icon is passed
    • ImageIcon?
    • MarsIcon?
    • . . .?
  • The actual type of anIcon is not Icon
  • There are no objects of type Icon
  • anIcon belongs to a class that implements Icon
  • That class defines a getIconWidth method

A Variable of Interface Type [11/41]

Polymorphism [12/41]

  • Which getIconWidth method is called?
  • Could be
    • MarsIcon.getIconWidth
    • ImageIcon.getIconWidth
    • . . .
  • Depends on object to which anIcon reference points, e.g.
    showMessageDialog(..., new MarsIcon(50))
  • Polymorphism: Select different methods according to actual object type

Benefits of Polymorphism [13/41]

  • Loose coupling
    • showMessageDialog decoupled from ImageIcon
    • Doesn't need to know about image processing
  • Extensibility
    • Client can supply new icon types

The Comparable Interface Type [14/41]

  • Collections  has static sort method:
    ArrayList<E> a = . . .
    Collections.sort(a);
  • Objects in list must implement the Comparable interface type
    public interface Comparable<T>
    {
     int compareTo(T other);
    }
  • Interface is parameterized (like ArrayList)
  • Type parameter is type of other

The Comparable Interface Type [15/41]

  • object1.compareTo(object2) returns
    • Negative number if object1 less than object2
    • 0 if objects identical
    • Positive number if object1 greater than object2
  • sort method compares and rearranges elements
    if (object1.compareTo(object2) > 0) . . .
  • String class implements Comparable<String> interface type: lexicographic (dictionary) order
  • Country class: compare countries by area

file:horstmann/ch04_sort1/Country.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package horstmann.ch04_sort1;
00002: /**
00003:    A country with a name and area.
00004: */
00005: public class Country implements Comparable<Country>
00006: {
00007:    /**
00008:       Constructs a country.
00009:       @param aName the name of the country
00010:       @param anArea the area of the country
00011:    */
00012:    public Country(String aName, double anArea)
00013:    {
00014:       name = aName;
00015:       area = anArea;
00016:    }
00017: 
00018:    /**
00019:       Gets the name of the country.
00020:       @return the name
00021:    */
00022:    public String getName()
00023:    {
00024:       return name;
00025:    }
00026: 
00027:    /**
00028:       Gets the area of the country.
00029:       @return the area
00030:    */
00031:    public double getArea()
00032:    {
00033:       return area;
00034:    }
00035: 
00036: 
00037:    /**
00038:       Compares two countries by area.
00039:       @param other the other country
00040:       @return a negative number if this country has a smaller
00041:       area than otherCountry, 0 if the areas are the same,
00042:       a positive number otherwise
00043:    */
00044:    public int compareTo(Country other)
00045:    {
00046:       if (area < other.area) return -1;
00047:       if (area > other.area) return 1;
00048:       return 0;
00049:    }
00050: 
00051:    private String name;
00052:    private double area;
00053: }
00054:

file:horstmann/ch04_sort1/CountrySortTester.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package horstmann.ch04_sort1;
00002: import java.util.*;
00003: 
00004: public class CountrySortTester
00005: {
00006:    public static void main(String[] args)
00007:    {
00008:       ArrayList<Country> countries = new ArrayList<Country>();
00009:       countries.add(new Country("Uruguay", 176220));
00010:       countries.add(new Country("Thailand", 514000));
00011:       countries.add(new Country("Belgium", 30510));
00012: 
00013:       Collections.sort(countries);
00014:       // Now the array list is sorted by area
00015:       for (Country c : countries)
00016:          System.out.println(c.getName() + " " + c.getArea());
00017:    }
00018: }
00019:

The Comparator interface type [16/41]

  • How can we sort countries by name?
  • Can't implement Comparable twice!
  • Comparator interface type gives added flexibility
    public interface Comparator<T>
    {
       int compare(T obj1, T obj2);
    }
  • Pass comparator object to sort:
    Collections.sort(list, comp);

The Comparator interface type [17/41]

  • Comparator object is a function object
  • This particular comparator object has no state
  • State can be useful, e.g. flag to sort in ascending or descending order

file:horstmann/ch04_sort2/CountryComparatorByName.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package horstmann.ch04_sort2;
00002: import java.util.*;
00003: 
00004: public class CountryComparatorByName implements Comparator<Country>
00005: {
00006:    public int compare(Country country1, Country country2)
00007:    {
00008:       return country1.getName().compareTo(country2.getName());
00009:    }
00010: 
00011: }
00012:

file:horstmann/ch04_sort2/ComparatorTester.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package horstmann.ch04_sort2;
00002: import java.util.*;
00003: 
00004: public class ComparatorTester
00005: {
00006:    public static void main(String[] args)
00007:    {
00008:       ArrayList<Country> countries = new ArrayList<Country>();
00009:       countries.add(new Country("Uruguay", 176220));
00010:       countries.add(new Country("Thailand", 514000));
00011:       countries.add(new Country("Belgium", 30510));
00012:       Comparator<Country>  comp = new CountryComparatorByName();
00013:       Collections.sort(countries, comp);
00014:          // Now the array list is sorted by area
00015:       for (Country c : countries)
00016:         System.out.println(c.getName() + " " + c.getArea());
00017:    }
00018: }
00019: 
00020:

Anonymous Classes [18/41]

  • No need to name objects that are used only once
    Collections.sort(countries,
       new CountryComparatorByName());
  • No need to name classes that are used only once
    Comparator<Country> comp = new
       Comparator<Country>()
       {
          public int compare(Country country1, Country country2)
          { 
             return country1.getName().compareTo(country2.getName());
          } 
       };

Anonymous Classes [19/41]

  • anonymous new expression:
    • defines anonymous class that implements Comparator
    • defines compare method of that class
    • constructs one object of that class
  • Cryptic syntax for very useful feature

Anonymous Classes [20/41]

  • Commonly used in factory methods:
    public static Comparator<Country> comparatorByName()
    {
       return new Comparator<Country>()
       {
          public int compare(Country country1, Country country2)
          { . . . }
       };
    }
  • Collections.sort(a, Country.comparatorByName());
  • Neat arrangement if multiple comparators make sense
    (by name, by area, ...)

Frames [21/41]

  • Frame window has decorations
    • title bar
    • close box
    • provided by windowing system
  • JFrame frame = new JFrame();
    frame.pack();
    frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
    frame.setVisible(true);

Adding Components [22/41]

  • Construct components
    JButton helloButton = new JButton("Say Hello");
  • Set frame layout
    frame.setLayout(new FlowLayout());
  • Add components to frame
    frame.add(helloButton);

file:horstmann/ch04_frame/FrameTester.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package horstmann.ch04_frame;
00002: import java.awt.*;
00003: import javax.swing.*;
00004: 
00005: public class FrameTester
00006: {
00007:    public static void main(String[] args)
00008:    {
00009:       JFrame frame = new JFrame();
00010: 
00011:       JButton helloButton = new JButton("Say Hello");
00012:       JButton goodbyeButton = new JButton("Say Goodbye");
00013: 
00014:       final int FIELD_WIDTH = 20;
00015:       JTextField textField = new JTextField(FIELD_WIDTH);
00016:       textField.setText("Click a button!");
00017: 
00018:       frame.setLayout(new FlowLayout());
00019: 
00020:       frame.add(helloButton);
00021:       frame.add(goodbyeButton);
00022:       frame.add(textField);
00023: 
00024:       frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
00025:       frame.pack();
00026:       frame.setVisible(true);
00027:    }
00028: }
00029:

User Interface Actions [23/41]

  • Previous program's buttons don't have any effect
  • Add listener object(s) to button
  • Belong to class implementing ActionListener interface type 
    public interface ActionListener
    {
       int actionPerformed(ActionEvent event);
    }
  • Listeners are notified when button is clicked

User Interface Actions [24/41]

  • Add action code into  actionPerformed method
  • Gloss over routine code
helloButton.addActionListener(new
   ActionListener()
   {
      public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent event)
      {
          textField.setText("Hello, World");
     }
   });
  • When button is clicked, text field is set

Accessing Variables from Enclosing Scope [25/41]

  • Remarkable: Inner class can access variables from enclosing scope
    e.g. textField
  • Can access enclosing instance fields, local variables
  • Local variables must be marked final
    final JTextField textField = ...;

User Interface Actions [26/41]

  • Constructor attaches listener:
    helloButton.addActionListener(listener);
  • Button remembers all listeners
  • When button clicked, button notifies listeners
    listener.actionPerformed(event);
  • Listener sets text of text field
    textField.setText("Hello, World!");

file:horstmann/ch04_action1/ActionTester.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package horstmann.ch04_action1;
00002: import java.awt.*;
00003: import java.awt.event.*;
00004: import javax.swing.*;
00005: 
00006: public class ActionTester
00007: {
00008:    public static void main(String[] args)
00009:    {
00010:       JFrame frame = new JFrame();
00011: 
00012:       final int FIELD_WIDTH = 20;
00013:       final JTextField textField = new JTextField(FIELD_WIDTH);
00014:       textField.setText("Click a button!");
00015: 
00016:       JButton helloButton = new JButton("Say Hello");
00017: 
00018:       helloButton.addActionListener(new
00019:          ActionListener()
00020:          {
00021:             public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent event)
00022:             {
00023:                textField.setText("Hello, World!");
00024:             }
00025:          });
00026: 
00027:       JButton goodbyeButton = new JButton("Say Goodbye");
00028: 
00029:       goodbyeButton.addActionListener(new
00030:          ActionListener()
00031:          {
00032:             public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent event)
00033:             {
00034:                textField.setText("Goodbye, World!");
00035:             }
00036:          });
00037: 
00038:       frame.setLayout(new FlowLayout());
00039: 
00040:       frame.add(helloButton);
00041:       frame.add(goodbyeButton);
00042:       frame.add(textField);
00043: 
00044:       frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
00045:       frame.pack();
00046:       frame.setVisible(true);
00047:    }
00048: }
00049:

Constructing Related Actions [27/41]

  • Write helper method that constructs objects
  • Pass variable information as parameters
  • Declare parameters final
public static ActionListener createGreetingButtonListener(
   final String message)
{
 return new
    ActionListener()
    {
       public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent event)
       {
          textField.setText(message);
       }
    };
}

Timers [28/41]

  • Supply delay, action listener
    ActionListener listener = ...;
    final int DELAY = 1000; // 1000 millisec = 1 sec
    Timer t = new Timer(DELAY, listener);
    t.start();
  • Action listener called when delay elapsed

file:horstmann/ch04_timer/TimerTester.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package horstmann.ch04_timer;
00002: import java.awt.*;
00003: import java.awt.event.*;
00004: import java.util.*;
00005: import javax.swing.*;
00006: import javax.swing.Timer;
00007: 
00008: /**
00009:    This program shows a clock that is updated once per second.
00010: */
00011: public class TimerTester
00012: {
00013:    public static void main(String[] args)
00014:    {
00015:       JFrame frame = new JFrame();
00016: 
00017:       final int FIELD_WIDTH = 20;
00018:       final JTextField textField = new JTextField(FIELD_WIDTH);
00019: 
00020:       frame.setLayout(new FlowLayout());
00021:       frame.add(textField);
00022: 
00023:       ActionListener listener = new
00024:          ActionListener()
00025:          {
00026:             public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent event)
00027:             {
00028:                Date now = new Date();
00029:                textField.setText(now.toString());
00030:             }
00031:          };
00032:       final int DELAY = 1000;
00033:          // Milliseconds between timer ticks
00034:       Timer t = new Timer(DELAY, listener);
00035:       t.start();
00036: 
00037:       frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
00038:       frame.pack();
00039:       frame.setVisible(true);
00040:    }
00041: }
00042:

Drawing Shapes [29/41]

  • paintIcon method receives graphics context of type Graphics
  • Actually a Graphics2D object in modern Java versions
    public void paintIcon(Component c, Graphics g, int x, int y)
    {
     Graphics2D g2 = (Graphics2D)g;
     . . .
    }
  • Can draw any object that implements Shape interface
    Shape s = . . .;
    g2.draw(s);

Drawing Rectangles and Ellipses [30/41]

  • Rectangle2D.Double constructed with
    • top left corner
    • width
    • height
  • g2.draw(new Rectangle2D.Double(x, y, width, height));
  • For Ellipse2D.Double, specify bounding box

Drawing Ellipses [31/41]



Drawing Line Segments [32/41]

  • Point2D.Double is a point in the plane
  • Line2D.Double joins to points
    Point2D.Double start = new Point2D.Double(x1, y1);
    Point2D.Double end = new Point2D.Double(x2, y2);
    Shape segment = new Line2D.Double(start, end);
    g2.draw(segment);

Relationship Between Shape Classes [33/41]


Drawing Text [34/41]

  • g2.drawString(text, x, y);
  • x, y are base point coordinates

Filling Shapes [35/41]

  • Fill interior of shape
    g2.fill(shape);
  • Set color for fills or strokes:
    g2.setColor(Color.red);
  • Program that draws car

file:horstmann/ch04_icon3/CarIcon.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: 
00002: package horstmann.ch04_icon3;
00003: import java.awt.*;
00004: import java.awt.geom.*;
00005: import javax.swing.*;
00006: 
00007: /**
00008:    An icon that has the shape of a car.
00009: */
00010: public class CarIcon implements Icon
00011: {
00012:    /**
00013:       Constructs a car of a given width.
00014:       @param aWidth the width of the car
00015:    */
00016:    public CarIcon(int aWidth)
00017:    {
00018:       width = aWidth;
00019:    }
00020:    
00021:    public int getIconWidth()
00022:    {
00023:       return width;
00024:    }
00025: 
00026:    public int getIconHeight()
00027:    {
00028:       return width / 2;
00029:    }
00030: 
00031:    public void paintIcon(Component c, Graphics g, int x, int y)
00032:    {
00033:       Graphics2D g2 = (Graphics2D) g;
00034:       Rectangle2D.Double body
00035:             = new Rectangle2D.Double(x, y + width / 6, 
00036:                   width - 1, width / 6);
00037:       Ellipse2D.Double frontTire
00038:             = new Ellipse2D.Double(x + width / 6, y + width / 3, 
00039:                   width / 6, width / 6);
00040:       Ellipse2D.Double rearTire
00041:             = new Ellipse2D.Double(x + width * 2 / 3, y + width / 3,
00042:                   width / 6, width / 6);
00043: 
00044:       // The bottom of the front windshield
00045:       Point2D.Double r1
00046:             = new Point2D.Double(x + width / 6, y + width / 6);
00047:       // The front of the roof
00048:       Point2D.Double r2
00049:             = new Point2D.Double(x + width / 3, y);
00050:       // The rear of the roof
00051:       Point2D.Double r3
00052:             = new Point2D.Double(x + width * 2 / 3, y);
00053:       // The bottom of the rear windshield
00054:       Point2D.Double r4
00055:             = new Point2D.Double(x + width * 5 / 6, y + width / 6);
00056: 
00057:       Line2D.Double frontWindshield
00058:             = new Line2D.Double(r1, r2);
00059:       Line2D.Double roofTop
00060:             = new Line2D.Double(r2, r3);
00061:       Line2D.Double rearWindshield
00062:             = new Line2D.Double(r3, r4);
00063: 
00064:       g2.fill(frontTire);
00065:       g2.fill(rearTire);
00066:       g2.setColor(Color.red);
00067:       g2.fill(body);
00068:       g2.draw(frontWindshield);
00069:       g2.draw(roofTop);
00070:       g2.draw(rearWindshield);
00071:    }
00072: 
00073:    private int width;
00074: }
00075: 
00076: 
00077:

Defining a New Interface Type [36/41]

  • Use timer to move car shapes
  • Draw car with CarShape
  • Two responsibilities:
    • Draw shape
    • Move shape
  • Define new interface type MoveableShape

CRC Card for the MoveableShape Interface Type [37/41]



Defining a New Interface Type [38/41]

  • Name the methods to conform to standard library
  • public interface MoveableShape
    {
       void draw(Graphics2D g2);
       void translate(int dx, int dy);
    }
  • CarShape class implements MoveableShape
    public class CarShape implements MoveableShape
    {
       public void translate(int dx, int dy)
       { x += dx; y += dy; }
       . . .
    }

Implementing the Animation [39/41]

  • Label contains icon that draws shape
  • Timer action moves shape, calls repaint on label
  • Label needs Icon, we have MoveableShape
  • Supply ShapeIcon adapter class
  • ShapeIcon.paintIcon calls MoveableShape.draw

Implementing the Animation [40/41]

file:horstmann/ch04_animation/MoveableShape.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package horstmann.ch04_animation;
00002: import java.awt.*;
00003: 
00004: /**
00005:    A shape that can be moved around.
00006: */
00007: public interface MoveableShape
00008: {
00009:    /**
00010:       Draws the shape.
00011:       @param g2 the graphics context
00012:    */
00013:    void draw(Graphics2D g2);
00014:    /**
00015:       Moves the shape by a given amount.
00016:       @param dx the amount to translate in x-direction
00017:       @param dy the amount to translate in y-direction
00018:    */
00019:    void translate(int dx, int dy);
00020: }
00021:

file:horstmann/ch04_animation/ShapeIcon.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package horstmann.ch04_animation;
00002: import java.awt.*;
00003: import java.util.*;
00004: import javax.swing.*;
00005: 
00006: /**
00007:    An icon that contains a moveable shape.
00008: */
00009: public class ShapeIcon implements Icon
00010: {
00011:    public ShapeIcon(MoveableShape shape,
00012:       int width, int height)
00013:    {
00014:       this.shape = shape;
00015:       this.width = width;
00016:       this.height = height;
00017:    }
00018:    
00019:    public int getIconWidth()
00020:    {
00021:       return width;
00022:    }
00023: 
00024:    public int getIconHeight()
00025:    {
00026:       return height;
00027:    }
00028: 
00029:    public void paintIcon(Component c, Graphics g, int x, int y)
00030:    {
00031:       Graphics2D g2 = (Graphics2D) g;
00032:       shape.draw(g2);
00033:    }
00034: 
00035:    private int width;
00036:    private int height;
00037:    private MoveableShape shape;
00038: }
00039: 
00040: 
00041:

file:horstmann/ch04_animation/AnimationTester.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package horstmann.ch04_animation;
00002: import java.awt.*;
00003: import java.awt.event.*;
00004: import javax.swing.*;
00005: 
00006: /**
00007:    This program implements an animation that moves
00008:    a car shape.
00009: */
00010: public class AnimationTester
00011: {
00012:    public static void main(String[] args)
00013:    {
00014:       JFrame frame = new JFrame();
00015: 
00016:       final MoveableShape shape
00017:             = new CarShape(0, 0, CAR_WIDTH);
00018: 
00019:       ShapeIcon icon = new ShapeIcon(shape,
00020:             ICON_WIDTH, ICON_HEIGHT);
00021: 
00022:       final JLabel label = new JLabel(icon);
00023:       frame.setLayout(new FlowLayout());
00024:       frame.add(label);
00025: 
00026:       frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
00027:       frame.pack();
00028:       frame.setVisible(true);
00029: 
00030:       final int DELAY = 100;
00031:       // Milliseconds between timer ticks
00032:       Timer t = new Timer(DELAY, new
00033:          ActionListener()
00034:          {
00035:             public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent event)
00036:             {
00037:                shape.translate(1, 0);
00038:                label.repaint();
00039:             }
00040:          });
00041:       t.start();
00042:    }
00043: 
00044:    private static final int ICON_WIDTH = 400;
00045:    private static final int ICON_HEIGHT = 100;
00046:    private static final int CAR_WIDTH = 100;
00047: }
00048:

file:horstmann/ch04_animation/CarShape.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package horstmann.ch04_animation;
00002: import java.awt.*;
00003: import java.awt.geom.*;
00004: import java.util.*;
00005: 
00006: /**
00007:    A car that can be moved around.
00008: */
00009: public class CarShape implements MoveableShape
00010: {
00011:    /**
00012:       Constructs a car item.
00013:       @param x the left of the bounding rectangle
00014:       @param y the top of the bounding rectangle
00015:       @param width the width of the bounding rectangle
00016:    */
00017:    public CarShape(int x, int y, int width)
00018:    {
00019:       this.x = x;
00020:       this.y = y;
00021:       this.width = width;
00022:    }
00023: 
00024:    public void translate(int dx, int dy)
00025:    {
00026:       x += dx;
00027:       y += dy;
00028:    }
00029: 
00030:    public void draw(Graphics2D g2)
00031:    {
00032:       Rectangle2D.Double body
00033:             = new Rectangle2D.Double(x, y + width / 6, 
00034:                   width - 1, width / 6);
00035:       Ellipse2D.Double frontTire
00036:             = new Ellipse2D.Double(x + width / 6, y + width / 3, 
00037:                   width / 6, width / 6);
00038:       Ellipse2D.Double rearTire
00039:             = new Ellipse2D.Double(x + width * 2 / 3, y + width / 3,
00040:                   width / 6, width / 6);
00041: 
00042:       // The bottom of the front windshield
00043:       Point2D.Double r1
00044:             = new Point2D.Double(x + width / 6, y + width / 6);
00045:       // The front of the roof
00046:       Point2D.Double r2
00047:             = new Point2D.Double(x + width / 3, y);
00048:       // The rear of the roof
00049:       Point2D.Double r3
00050:             = new Point2D.Double(x + width * 2 / 3, y);
00051:       // The bottom of the rear windshield
00052:       Point2D.Double r4
00053:             = new Point2D.Double(x + width * 5 / 6, y + width / 6);
00054:       Line2D.Double frontWindshield
00055:             = new Line2D.Double(r1, r2);
00056:       Line2D.Double roofTop
00057:             = new Line2D.Double(r2, r3);
00058:       Line2D.Double rearWindshield
00059:             = new Line2D.Double(r3, r4);
00060:       
00061:       g2.draw(body);
00062:       g2.draw(frontTire);
00063:       g2.draw(rearTire);
00064:       g2.draw(frontWindshield);
00065:       g2.draw(roofTop);
00066:       g2.draw(rearWindshield);
00067:    }
00068:    
00069:    private int x;
00070:    private int y;
00071:    private int width;
00072: }
00073:

Implementing the Animation [41/41]
